sen.j: 渡辺 政香（わたなべ まさか、安永5年7月16日 (旧暦)（1776年） - 天保11年9月28日 (旧暦)（1840年））は、江戸時代の国学者・神職。
sen.e: Masaka WATANABE (August 29, 1776 - October 23, 1840) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and Shinto priest in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「安永5年7月16日」＝グレゴリオ暦「西暦1776年8月29日 」、「天保11年9月28日」＝グレゴリオ暦「西暦1840年10月23日 」、出典：http://maechan.net/kanreki
sen.e: Masaka WATANABE (August 29, 1776 - October 23, 1840) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and Shinto priest in the Edo period.
Masaka WATANABE (August 29, 1776 - October 23, 1840) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and Shinto priest in the Edo period.

sen.j: 『参河誌』『鴨の騒立』の編纂者として知られている。
sen.e: He is known as the compiler of "Mikawashi" (materials on the Mikawa) and "Kamo no Sawadachi" (the Kamo riot).
He is known as the compiler of "Mikawashi" (materials on the Mikawa) and "Kamo no Sawadachi" (the Kamo riot).
He is known as the compiler of "Mikawashi" (materials on the Mikawa) and "Kamo no Sawadachi" (the Kamo riot).

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 渡辺政香は1776年に三河国幡豆郡寺津村（現在の愛知県西尾市）の寺津八幡社で代々神職を務める家に生まれた。
sen.e: Masaka WATANABE was born in 1776 as a child of a family which served as Shinto priest of Terazu Hachimansha (Terazu shrine) for generations in Terazu-mura Village, Hazunokori County, Mikawa Province (present Nishio City, Aichi Prefecture).

Masaka WATANABE was born in 1776 as a child of a family which served as Shinto priest of Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine for generations in Terazu Village, Hazu County, Mikawa Province (present Nishio City, Aichi Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Terazu Hachimansha (Terazu shrine)→Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine、Terazu-mura Village→Terazu Village、Hazunokori County→Hazu Countyとしました。
sen.e: Masaka WATANABE was born in 1776 as a child of a family which served as Shinto priest of Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine for generations in Terazu Village, Hazu County, Mikawa Province (present Nishio City, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: 父は渡辺助三郎、母、りや。
sen.e: His father was Sukesaburo WATANABE and his mother was Riya.
His father was Sukesaburo WATANABE and his mother was Riya.
His father was Sukesaburo WATANABE and his mother was Riya.

sen.j: 1790年（寛政2年）に浜島錦城（文貞・文亭）に入門し和漢の史籍を学ぶ。
sen.e: He became a disciple of Kinjo HAMAJIMA (Bunjo and Buntei) in 1790 and learned Japanese and Chinese historical works.
He became a disciple of Kinjo HAMAJIMA (Bunjo and Buntei) in 1790 and learned Japanese and Chinese historical works.
He became a disciple of Kinjo HAMAJIMA (Bunjo and Buntei) in 1790 and learned Japanese and Chinese historical works.

sen.j: この時に『参河誌』の編集を決意する。
sen.e: At this time, he made up his mind to compile "Mikawashi."
At this time, he made up his mind to compile "Mikawashi."
At this time, he made up his mind to compile "Mikawashi."

sen.j: この後、伊勢国の漢詩人の山口凹巷に師事した。
sen.e: Afterward, he studied under Tenan YAMAGUCHI, a composer of Chinese poems in Isa Province.
Afterward, he studied under Tenan YAMAGUCHI, a composer of Chinese poems in Ise Province.
Afterward, he studied under Tenan YAMAGUCHI, a composer of Chinese poems in Ise Province.

sen.j: 1799年（寛政11年）に渡辺家14代目として家督を相続し、1807年（文化 (元号)4年）に京都の神祇官白川伯王家に入門した。
sen.e: He succeeded his father as the 14th head of Watanabe family in 1799 and became a disciple of Jingikan (department of worship), the Shirakawa-hakuo family in 1807.
He succeeded his father as the 14th head of Watanabe family in 1799 and became a disciple of Jingikan (department of worship), the Shirakawa-hakuo family in 1807.
He succeeded his father as the 14th head of Watanabe family in 1799 and became a disciple of Jingikan (department of worship), the Shirakawa-hakuo family in 1807.

sen.j: 1823年（文政6年）には伊勢の国学者、足代弘訓に和歌を学んでいる。
sen.e: He learned Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) from Hironori AJIRO, a scholar of Japanese classical literature of Isa Province in 1823.
He learned Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) from Hironori AJIRO, a scholar of Japanese classical literature of Ise Province in 1823.
He learned Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) from Hironori AJIRO, a scholar of Japanese classical literature of Ise Province in 1823.

sen.j: 同じ三河の羽田野敬雄（羽田八幡宮文庫（現・愛知県豊橋市）の創設者）とも交遊した。
sen.e: He associated also with Takao HATANO (The founder of the Haneda Hachimangu Bunko (the library of Haneda hachimangu) (present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture)) of the same Mikawa Province).
He associated also with Takao HATANO (The founder of the Haneda Hachimangu Bunko [the library of Haneda Hachiman-gu Shrine], present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture) of the same Mikawa Province.
sen.cmt: カッコ表記修正、the library of Haneda Hachiman-gu Shrineとしました。
sen.e: He associated also with Takao HATANO (The founder of the Haneda Hachimangu Bunko [the library of Haneda Hachiman-gu Shrine], present Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture) of the same Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 1836年（天保7年） に『参河誌』が完成する。
sen.e: He completed "Mikawashi" in 1836.
He completed "Mikawashi" in 1836.
He completed "Mikawashi" in 1836.

sen.j: 同年9月に三河国加茂郡 (三河国)で起こった一揆を『鴨の騒立』に、同月の寺津村の一揆では、その調停をすると共に『寺津村旧記』に記録した。
sen.e: He recorded in "Kamo no Sawadachi" the Ikki (uprising) which took place in October in the same year in Kamo-gun County, Mikawa Province, and, mediated the Ikki of Terazu-mura Village in the same month and recorded it in "Terazu Village Kyuki" (the record for Terazu Village).
sen.cmt: 「天保7年9月」＝グレゴリオ暦「西暦1836年10月10日 」、出典：http://maechan.net/kanreki
sen.e: He recorded in "Kamo no Sawadachi" the Ikki (uprising) which took place in October in the same year in Kamo County, Mikawa Province, and, mediated the Ikki of Terazu Village in the same month and recorded it in "Terazu Village Kyuki" (the record for Terazu Village).
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、Kamo-gun County→Kamo County、Terazu-mura Village→Terazu Villageとしました。
sen.e: He recorded in "Kamo no Sawadachi" the Ikki (uprising) which took place in October in the same year in Kamo County, Mikawa Province, and, mediated the Ikki of Terazu Village in the same month and recorded it in "Terazu Village Kyuki" (the record for Terazu Village).

sen.j: 1840年（天保11年）に64歳で亡くなった。
sen.e: He died at the age of 64 in 1840.
He died at the age of 64 in 1840.
He died at the age of 64 in 1840.

sen.j: 後年、寺津八幡社に顕彰碑が建てられている。
sen.e: Later, a monument of honor was set up at Terazu Hachimansha (Terazu shrine).
Later, a monument of honor was set up at Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine.
sen.cmt: Terazu Hachimansha (Terazu shrine)→Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrineとしました。
sen.e: Later, a monument of honor was set up at Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine.

sen.j: 号・字・通称
sen.e: Go (pseudonym), Azana (adult males nickname), Common name
Go (pseudonym), Azana (adult males nickname), Common name
Go (pseudonym), Azana (adult males nickname), Common name

sen.j: 渡辺政香は国学のほか漢詩や和歌などを学び、多くの学者や文人墨客と交流があった。
sen.e: Masaka WATANABE learned Chinese-style poem, Waka as well as Japanese classical literature and associated with many scholars, writers and artists.
Masaka WATANABE learned Chinese-style poem, Waka as well as Japanese classical literature and associated with many scholars, writers and artists.
Masaka WATANABE learned Chinese-style poem, Waka as well as Japanese classical literature and associated with many scholars, writers and artists.

sen.j: そのため多くの号（ごう）を用いていた。
sen.e: Therefore, he used many pseudonyms.
Therefore, he used many pseudonyms.
Therefore, he used many pseudonyms.

sen.j: 保宝葉園・磯泊散人・臥蝶園・仙雲亭寿山・同心軒などである。
sen.e: They included Hohogashiwa en, Sanjin SHIHATO, Fusecho en, Juzan Senuntei and Doshinken.
sen.cmt: 「保宝葉園」は、下記サイトを参考にしました。www.asahi-net.or.jp/~sg2h-ymst/yakayak2.html
sen.e: They included Hohogashiwa en, Shihato Sanjin, Fusecho en, Senuntei Juzan and Doshinken.
sen.cmt: 号のため、Sanjin SHIHATO→Shihato Sanjin、Juzan Senuntei→Senuntei Juzanとしました。
sen.e: They included Hohogashiwa en, Shihato Sanjin, Fusecho en, Senuntei Juzan and Doshinken.

sen.j: このうちの磯泊散人について、「磯泊（しはと）」とは和名類聚抄にある幡豆郡八郷うちの一つで「しはつ」とも読み、転じて幡豆の語源ともいわれる地名であり、それに号に添えて用いる語の「散人」を合わせたものである。
sen.e: As for Sanjin SHIHATO of the above, 'Shihato' was one of the eight Go (an administrative area larger than a village) in Hazu-gun County and was also read as 'Shihatsu,' which changed its meaning to the origin of the place name of Hazu, and 'Sanjin' used as a suffix to pseudonyms was added to it.
sen.cmt: 「八郷」については、用語集の「越前五郷 Echizen go-go (the five areas in Echizen province)［郷は村（village）よりも大きな行政単位のようですが、定訳は不明です」を参考に訳しました。
sen.e: As for Shihato Sanjin of the above, 'Shihato' was one of the eight Go (an administrative area larger than a village) in Hazu County and was also read as 'Shihatsu,' which changed its meaning to the origin of the place name of Hazu, and 'Sanjin' used as a suffix to pseudonyms was added to it.
sen.cmt: Sanjin SHIHATO→Shihato Sanjin、Hazu-gun County→Hazu Countyとしました。
sen.e: As for Shihato Sanjin of the above, 'Shihato' was one of the eight Go (an administrative area larger than a village) in Hazu County and was also read as 'Shihatsu,' which changed its meaning to the origin of the place name of Hazu, and 'Sanjin' used as a suffix to pseudonyms was added to it.

sen.j: また臥蝶園の「臥蝶（ふせちょう）」は寺津八幡社と縁の深い大河内氏の家紋である。
sen.e: Furthermore, 'Fusecho' of Fusecho en was the family crest of the Okochi clan which was closely connected with Terazu Hachimansha.
Furthermore, 'Fusecho' of Fusecho en was the family crest of the Okochi clan which was closely connected with Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine.
Furthermore, 'Fusecho' of Fusecho en was the family crest of the Okochi clan which was closely connected with Terazu Hachiman-sha Shrine.

sen.j: 字（あざな）は三善といい、通称は順輔・普磋吉・助太夫と名乗っていた。
sen.e: His Azana was Miyoshi and he called himself Junsuke, Fusakichi and Sukedayu as common names.
sen.cmt: 「三善」「順輔」「普磋吉」の読みは定かではありません。
sen.e: His Azana was Miyoshi (三善) and he called himself Junsuke (順輔), Fusakichi (普磋吉) and Sukedayu as common names.
sen.cmt: 「三善」「順輔」「普磋吉」→読み方不明のため漢字表記追加
sen.e: His Azana was Miyoshi (三善) and he called himself Junsuke (順輔), Fusakichi (普磋吉) and Sukedayu as common names.

sen.j: 評価
sen.e: Evaluation
Evaluation
Evaluation

sen.j: 和志取神社誌；大久保芳太郎編；矢作町（愛知県）；和志取神社社務所：明40．9では、政香の説は杜撰の評を免がれず、書上は贋物偽造の疑圑を免れず、と記載されている。
sen.e: The Accounts on Washitori -jinja Shrine; Compiled by Yoshitaro OKUBO; Yahagi-cho (Aichi Prefecture); The shrine office of Washitori -jinja Shrine: The September 1907 section described that the Masaka's theory could not avoid the criticism that it was careless and his papers could not avoid the doubt that he forged the fake.

The Accounts on Washitori -jinja Shrine; Compiled by Yoshitaro OKUBO; Yahagi-cho (Aichi Prefecture); The shrine office of Washitori-jinja Shrine: The September 1907 section described that the Masaka's theory could not avoid the criticism that it was careless and his papers could not avoid the doubt that he forged the fake.

The Accounts on Washitori -jinja Shrine; Compiled by Yoshitaro OKUBO; Yahagi-cho (Aichi Prefecture); The shrine office of Washitori-jinja Shrine: The September 1907 section described that the Masaka's theory could not avoid the criticism that it was careless and his papers could not avoid the doubt that he forged the fake.

sen.j: 延喜式式内社の鷲取天神は、安城市柿碕町和志取と水戸大日本史に明載されているにもかかわらず、碧海郡高取村（現在の高浜市高取）であると自説を強引に主張しているもの。
sen.e: In spite of the fact that Mito Dainihonshi (Great history of Japan compiled by Mito Domain) described Washitori Tenjin listed as a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) in the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) was in Washitori, Kakisaki-cho, Anjo City, Masaka aggressively insisted on his opinion that it was in Takatori-mura Village, Hekikai-gun County (present Takatori, Takahama City).
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」郵便番号検索では、「高浜市高取」の「高取」が見つかりません。
sen.e: In spite of the fact that Mito Dainihonshi (Great history of Japan compiled by Mito Domain) described Washitori Tenjin listed as a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) in the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) was in Washitori, Kakisaki-cho, Anjo City, Masaka aggressively insisted on his opinion that it was in Takatori Village, Hekikai County (present Takatori, Takahama City).
sen.cmt: Takatori-mura Village, Hekikai-gun County→Takatori Village, Hekikai Countyとしました。
sen.e: In spite of the fact that Mito Dainihonshi (Great history of Japan compiled by Mito Domain) described Washitori Tenjin listed as a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) in the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) was in Washitori, Kakisaki-cho, Anjo City, Masaka aggressively insisted on his opinion that it was in Takatori Village, Hekikai County (present Takatori, Takahama City).

sen.j: 参河誌などの渡辺政香の著作物は、自説のゴリ押し、に注意する必要がある。
sen.e: As for the works of Masaka WATANABE including Mikawashi, it is necessary to be careful about his unreasonable insistence of his own opinions.
As for the works of Masaka WATANABE including Mikawashi, it is necessary to be careful about his unreasonable insistence of his own opinions.
As for the works of Masaka WATANABE including Mikawashi, it is necessary to be careful about his unreasonable insistence of his own opinions.
